div.p: Having Å¿hewed the Å¿trength of that State which doth conÅ¿iÅ¿t in the bond of union, and confederation among themÅ¿elves, and Allyance with forein Princes, I muÅ¿t now point out Å¿ome Å¿ymptomes of miÅ¿underÅ¿tandings and jealouÅ¿ies, which do indicate the weakneÅ¿s of that body, and threaten danger of the diÅ¿Å¿olution thereof in time.

The firÅ¿t, like original Å¿in, is derived from the birth, and firÅ¿t conception of their liberty, which hath drawn upon them, and upon their poÅ¿terity an hereditary ill talent of the houÅ¿e of AuÅ¿tria, who remembring very well that in former times they were Å¿overaign lords of all that province, will never forget the wrong which they do conceive

If this were granted, that freedom muÅ¿t be confined within the walls of thoÅ¿e Towns, & cannot be extended unto the inlargement of their dominion, wherein they have more then any one Canton, of what did anciently belong unto the AuÅ¿triaci, and the BerneÅ¿i have a Å¿pecial

The particular miÅ¿underÅ¿tandings are Å¿o much the more to be fear'd, as internal miÅ¿chiefes are more dangerous then external; they are many, and have Å¿everal branches, but may be reduced all unto one head, and that is an alienation of affections, hatred and rancor cauÅ¿ed by their diviÅ¿ion, in matter of religion. whereof they do make profeÅ¿Å¿ion, the orthodox Helvetians being a principal member of the reformed Church, and having like a Seminary produced men of extraotdinary learning and zeal, who have laboured in the vineyard of reformation, with much paines and great profit to the Church, Å¿uch as were Zuinglius, Oecolampdius, Simler, HoÅ¿pinian, WaÅ¿er, and many others who for converting of Å¿ouls, do now Å¿hine in heaven, like Å¿tars in the firmament. ThoÅ¿e who do foment the Catholicks, have divers ends, for although it may be preÅ¿umed that the Pope doth intend nothing but the reduction of that whole body to the obedience of the Å¿ea of Rome, wherein likewiÅ¿e there is Å¿o much mixture of worldly reÅ¿pect, as the increaÅ¿e of Å¿piritual Faires and Markets, do fill his coffers by the vent of his indulgences and pardons, yet it is certain, that the Emperour and the King of Spain have ragione di Å¿tato, which doth move them to adhere and take part with the Catholick Cantons. For beÅ¿ides that thoÅ¿e diviÅ¿ions and factions, are like the cutting of SamÅ¿ons locks, the Å¿trength of that body conÅ¿iÅ¿ting in union, as his
did in his hair, if at any time they can prevail Å¿o far, as to kindle a war in thoÅ¿e parts grounded upon religion, they will Å¿oon make an end of the quarrel, by Å¿etting upon both, parties when they have weakened one another; this deÅ¿igne is Å¿o well grounded, that it may perhaps rake effect in time, for Å¿ince the reception of the JeÅ¿uits in Iucerne and Friburg, exacerbations have daily increaÅ¿ed, and nothing but the fear of a foreign enemy doth keep them now from a civil war. div.head: Of the form of Govenrment.
div.p:

I will note Å¿ome few, becauÅ¿e I cannot take notice of all. 1. That Regiments be kept intire, and quartered together, not lodging one company in one place, and another in an other. 3. div.head: Of the extention of Helvetia.

div.p:

The King of Sweden, GuÅ¿tavus, hath lately added a new example to confirm the old poÅ¿ition, and if his proceedings be underÅ¿tod as IncurÅ¿ions, and not as ConqueÅ¿ts, they will have perfect conformitie with the firÅ¿t generally received poÅ¿ition.

He did firÅ¿t paÅ¿Å¿e the Baltick Å¿ea, with an army of no great conÅ¿ideration; and did hazard himÅ¿elf upon Å¿ome diÅ¿advantages; for he could not land upon any ground, which he was not firÅ¿t to diÅ¿pute with his Å¿word, and was to incounter at his beginning with ImperialiÅ¿ts, who having many yeers Å¿ucked the blood of poor Martyrs in that Country, would not render it without hazard of their own. Put into his balance the land troups which he had in PruÅ¿Å¿ia and Livonia, I will confeÅ¿Å¿e, that the hope of joyning with them (although they were far off) did incourage him and his naval army, to adventure upon an enterpriÅ¿e that was little better then deÅ¿perate, for although he did well know, that the ImperialiÅ¿ts
were hated in thoÅ¿e parts for the cruelties and extortions which they had committed a long time, and that he Å¿hould be received of all good Patriots as a Protector of the publick liberty, yet was he to break the ice of himÅ¿elf, there being none that did dare to appear in his favour, untill he had no need of the favour of their appearing. It is more then eight years Å¿ince the ImperialiÅ¿ts have looked toward the North, preÅ¿uming (and with good ground) that if they could be MaÅ¿ters of the Rivers and that Å¿ea, all Germany was to be at their devotion. None went further then ValleÅ¿tein, who did Å¿erve his MaÅ¿ter well, and loÅ¿e nothing by the bargain. This was the onely man, to Å¿peak humanly, that could have Å¿topped the King of Sweden at the beginning; for the Emperour having given unto him the inveÅ¿titure of the Dutchy of Mechelbourg, he was able of himÅ¿elf to have maintained his poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion; but the Duke of Bavaria and the Catholick league having conÅ¿trained the Emperour at the laÅ¿t Dyet of RatiÅ¿bone to licence him, he retired to
Prague, and Tilly having the general command under the Duke of Bavaria, did not care to fortifie the maritime places of Pomerany and Mechelburg, becauÅ¿e they did belong to ValleÅ¿tein, whoÅ¿e ruin the Duke of Bavaria did Å¿eek, and if Tilly could have been Å¿ure that the king of Sweden would have contented himÅ¿elf with the reintegration of the Dukes of Mechelbourg, and Prince of Pomerany, and what with the ImperialiÅ¿ts had gotten in the Dutchy of HolÅ¿tein, he would never have appeared as an enemy, there being nothing that the Duke of Bavaria, and he did deÅ¿ire more then the ruin of ValleÅ¿tein, the diÅ¿crediting the Emperour, and the exaltation of the Catholick league which might in due time authorize Bavaria to make a king of the Romans according to his own minde, and Å¿tampt at Munichen. Now if it be rightly examined, it will appear that the king of Sweden hath not Å¿pent Å¿o many months Å¿ince his departure from Sweden, and his arrival in Francony and Suevia, as the ImperialiÅ¿ts did Å¿pend years in conquering North-wards: and
the facility of his progreÅ¿Å¿e is to be attributed unto the finger of God, and not unto the arm of fleÅ¿h.

This is taken pro conceÅ¿Å¿o, that he hath aÅ¿Å¿ured himÅ¿elf of the Baltick Å¿ea for his retraite, that he hath infranchiÅ¿ed Pomeranie, Mechelbourg, and HolÅ¿tein, that he hath cleared the beÅ¿t parts of the rivers of Elbe and WeÅ¿er, that he hath put the Circle of lower Saxony in Å¿tate of defence, Å¿ecured the Marquis of Brandebourg, Å¿aved the Duke Elector of Saxony from utter perdition, Å¿eated himÅ¿elf of the BiÅ¿hopricks of Bamberg, and Werteberg, incouraged the Landgraves of HeÅ¿Å¿e, and diÅ¿poÅ¿ed the capital Imperial Towns of Francony and Swevia to accept him as Protector of the common liberty. This is very much to be done in Å¿o Å¿hort a time, but it was not done Å¿ine Å¿anguine & Å¿udore; for when Tilly did Å¿ee that the king had paÅ¿Å¿ed the Elbe, he did look that way, to Å¿top his further advancing, and upon the confines of that river there did paÅ¿Å¿e many rencounters which were very bloudy, but
the main battle was given near LipÅ¿wick, wherein God did bleÅ¿Å¿e the king, and our Laity did not favour Tilly. It cannot be denied but that he did the part of a brave General in that battle, and in all the former rencounters, & he hath now diÅ¿covered an errour in our ordinary Arithmetick, for that Hydra of his, hath Å¿till multiplied by Å¿ubÅ¿traction, and he is now as Å¿trong as ever he was. It is therefore neceÅ¿Å¿ary that we Å¿hould examin well how things do Å¿tand at the preÅ¿ent, foreÅ¿ee what is likely to inÅ¿ue and deliberate quid agendum.

In my conceit, things do Å¿tand yet in aequilibrio, for although much ground hath been gotten Å¿ince the battle near LypÅ¿wich, and the hearts of milions of men are turned to our favour in deteÅ¿tation of the cruelty which the Imperial CommiÅ¿Å¿aries have uÅ¿ed; yet if the chance of the war do turn in an other battel to our diÅ¿advantage, all that ground is loÅ¿t, and thoÅ¿e people will return tanquam canes ad vomitum, let us take it for granted, that the king
of Sweden may go into the field with twenty thouÅ¿and foot and five thouÅ¿and horÅ¿e, not counting his garriÅ¿ons. He will be encountered by Tilly and Lorain with as many, if not more. If the ImperialiÅ¿ts get the day, we may Å¿ay good night, unleÅ¿Å¿e we will deceive our Å¿elves. If the king prevail, it is not Å¿o, for he pretending nothing in Germany for himÅ¿elf, but intending the repatriation of divers exiled princes, and proÅ¿cribed States, they will not be able to Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t Å¿everally of themÅ¿elves without him, nor he be able to maintain his army, if he do give every man is due, and retain nothing unto himÅ¿elf, which may inable him to maintain both himÅ¿elf, and thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e protection he doth undertake. Herein I do finde a great difficulty; for if he do live wholy upon the Catholick Princes, our civil diÅ¿putes will terminate in a war of religion; and if he do live upon the ProteÅ¿tants, they will be as weary of him, as they are now of the Emperour: if he do exact from both, he will be in Å¿hort time equally odious to both, who will Å¿ee that they have changed Dominum
non Å¿ervitutem. But if the Emperour do loÅ¿e the day, he will not be Å¿o far Å¿treightned: for the reverent reÅ¿pect due unto his Imperial Crown wil alwayes keep in devotion to his Å¿ervice, milions of Å¿ouls, who do deteÅ¿t the barbarous proceedings of his MiniÅ¿ters. Secondly, the hereditary poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions of thÃ© houÅ¿e of AuÅ¿tria yeeld many men, and are of great extenÅ¿ion, which none can take from them in good conÅ¿cience. LaÅ¿tly, the dominions of the king of Spain are very vaÅ¿t, and his TreaÅ¿ure of Å¿uch conÅ¿ideration, that it is a ridiculous thing to think, that he can want mony; for although he doth Å¿omtimee turn banquerupt, when it doth turn him to account; yet he doth alwayes finde mony for his own occaÅ¿ions, and he that hath mony, Å¿hall never want men. His MajeÅ¿ty hath Å¿ent the Marquis Hamilton with forces to the King of Sweden, thoÅ¿e are counterballanced by the troups which the Duke of Lorain hath conducted in Å¿ervice of the Emperour. The Å¿tates may perhaps aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the king of Sweden with conÅ¿iderable troups, when they have
nothing to do; but it were better for him that they had Å¿omething to do, becauÅ¿e the Infanta will Å¿end as many to the Emperour as they can Å¿end to him, Å¿o that the ballance doth go equal at preÅ¿ent, but for the future, we have this diÅ¿advantage, that if we have this diÅ¿advantage, that if we be once beaten a Plat couÅ¿ture, we Å¿hall be worÅ¿e then before Prague, and if the Emperour loÅ¿e the day, he will prove like Anteus, and riÅ¿e from the ground with new Å¿trength, having a good pulÅ¿e of his patrimony, in the conÅ¿ervation whereof many are intereÅ¿Å¿ed.

The point moÅ¿t conÅ¿iderable is, that of religion, which we are like to fall upon, although we are to avoid it like a rock. If inevitable neceÅ¿Å¿ity do caÅ¿t us upon that deÅ¿perate coaÅ¿t, we muÅ¿t make account, that at this preÅ¿ent in Germany there is much ground poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by thoÅ¿e who do declare themÅ¿elves on our Å¿ide; and thus much enjoyed by our enemies declared, as may be Å¿een by a Å¿chedule apart, which Å¿hall be annexed into this diÅ¿courÅ¿e.

If we do confine our Å¿elves unto Germany onely, we Å¿hall get little by the bargain, and if we do go out, we Å¿hall loÅ¿e more. In Germany the Catholicks have this great advantage, that they do in Spiritualibus, all acknowledge the Pope, and do agree among themÅ¿elves in doctrine and diÅ¿cipline, whereas we have nothing but the confeÅ¿Å¿ion of AuÅ¿bourg, which doth binde us with Å¿o looÅ¿e a chain, that the names of CalviniÅ¿ts, Lutherans, HuÅ¿Å¿its are Å¿till in eÅ¿Å¿e, and their, and their hatred one againÅ¿t the other, greater then of them all againÅ¿t the Catholicks. If we do go out of upper Germany, there is Great Brittany, Denmark, Sweden, and the Å¿tates of the united Provinces, which do come Å¿hort of France, Spain, and Italy, who will be againÅ¿t us when we Å¿hall come to that point, for although this Pope be contrary in affection to the houÅ¿e of AuÅ¿tria, yet he muÅ¿t contribute what may lie in his power, to the maintaining of the Catholicks, and the like muÅ¿t be preÅ¿umed both of the French King, and of the Venetians and Duke of Savoy, who

I have heard Å¿ome Å¿ay, that we muÅ¿t truÅ¿t to our Å¿elves, and never expect any good from Catholicks; the firÅ¿t I grant, but I denie the Å¿econd. I will Å¿ay thoÅ¿e men are very wiÅ¿e that will demonÅ¿trate how ProteÅ¿tants thorowout Europe Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t without Å¿upport of Catholicks; but if we can be without them, it is good, becauÅ¿e they are to us like a lake of Anecie, which doth yeeld fiÅ¿h all the yeer, but in lent, as theÅ¿e may Å¿erve us at all times, but when we have moÅ¿t need of them. There is yet another thing of greater conÅ¿ideration, which doth make for us, and that is the difference among Catholicks for civil reÅ¿pects, which wil in part help to counterpoiÅ¿e the miÅ¿underÅ¿tandings of our religionaries in Germany, of which before I have Å¿poken; though France hath not hitherto Å¿o viÅ¿ibly aÅ¿pired to an univerÅ¿al Monarchy, as Spain is Å¿aid to have done, (perhaps unjuÅ¿tly) it is apparent that their perpetuall domeÅ¿tick brovilleries have hindered them from executing, and perhaps from projecting any Å¿uch vaÅ¿t deÅ¿ignes.
